**Lake George** is a [town](/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_New_York#Town
"Administrative divisions of New York") in [Warren
County](/wiki/Warren_County,_New_York "Warren County, New York"), [New
York](/wiki/New_York_\(state\) "New York \(state\)"), United States. The
population was 3,578 at the 2000 census.[2] The town is named after the lake,
[Lake George](/wiki/Lake_George_\(New_York\) "Lake George \(New York\)").
Within the town is a
[village](/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_New_York#Village "Administrative
divisions of New York") also named [Lake
George](/wiki/Lake_George_\(village\),_New_York "Lake George \(village\), New
York"). The town is part of the [Glens Falls Metropolitan Statistical
Area](/wiki/Glens_Falls_Metropolitan_Statistical_Area "Glens Falls
Metropolitan Statistical Area").[4]

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lake_George,_New_York&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

The first European to visit the lake was Father [Isaac
Jogues](/wiki/Isaac_Jogues "Isaac Jogues") in August 1642.[5] He was later
captured by [Mohawks](/wiki/Mohawk_people "Mohawk people"), escaped, and
returned home to France. In 1646, he was sent on a political mission to the
[Iroquois](/wiki/Iroquois "Iroquois") to propose a treaty of peace, and at
that point named the lake "Lac du Saint Sacrement" (Lake of the Blessed
Sacrament).[5]

In 1755, the lake was renamed "Lake George" by General [William
Johnson](/wiki/Sir_William_Johnson,_1st_Baronet "Sir William Johnson, 1st
Baronet") in honor of [King George II](/wiki/George_II_of_Great_Britain
"George II of Great Britain").[5]

Lake George was also the site of [Fort William Henry](/wiki/Fort_William_Henry
"Fort William Henry"), named in honor of [Prince William
Henry](/wiki/William_IV_of_the_United_Kingdom "William IV of the United
Kingdom"), grandson of King George II, by General Johnson. The fort, its
surrender to the [Marquis de Montcalm](/wiki/Louis-Joseph_de_Montcalm "Louis-
Joseph de Montcalm") after a six-day siege by the French and Indians, and the
following massacre all in 1757 were used by [James Fenimore
Cooper](/wiki/James_Fenimore_Cooper "James Fenimore Cooper") as the background
for his famous novel _[The Last of the
Mohicans](/wiki/The_Last_of_the_Mohicans "The Last of the Mohicans")_. The
fort was reconstructed and opened to the public as a museum in 1953.[5]

The town was established in 1810 as the "Town of Caldwell" from parts of the
towns of [Bolton](/wiki/Bolton,_New_York "Bolton, New York"),
[Queensbury](/wiki/Queensbury,_New_York "Queensbury, New York"), and
[Thurman](/wiki/Thurman,_New_York "Thurman, New York").[6] In 1962 the town
changed its name to Lake George.[5]

The town is also home to [Wiawaka](/wiki/Wiawaka "Wiawaka"), a historic
retreat center that was founded in 1903 for female textile workers from Troy
but operates as a nonprofit for everyone today.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The [FORWARD shipwreck site (motor launch)](/wiki/Forward_shipwreck_site
"Forward shipwreck site"), [Royal C. Peabody
Estate](/wiki/Royal_C._Peabody_Estate "Royal C. Peabody Estate"), [Wiawaka
Bateaux Site](/wiki/Wiawaka_Bateaux_Site "Wiawaka Bateaux Site"), and [Wiawaka
Holiday House](/wiki/Wiawaka_Holiday_House "Wiawaka Holiday House") are listed
on the [National Register of Historic
Places](/wiki/National_Register_of_Historic_Places "National Register of
Historic Places"). The [Land Tortoise (radeau) Shipwreck
Site](/wiki/Land_Tortoise_\(shipwreck\) "Land Tortoise \(shipwreck\)") and
[Owl's Nest](/wiki/Owl%27s_Nest "Owl's Nest") are [National Historic
Landmarks](/wiki/National_Historic_Landmark "National Historic Landmark").[7]
The [Lake George Battlefield Park Historic
District](/wiki/Lake_George_Battlefield_Park_Historic_District "Lake George
Battlefield Park Historic District") was listed in 2011.

##
Geography[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lake_George,_New_York&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Geography")]

According to the [United States Census
Bureau](/wiki/United_States_Census_Bureau "United States Census Bureau"), the
town has a total area of 32.7 square miles (84.7 km²), of which 30.2 square
miles (78.3 km²) is land and 2.5 square miles (6.3 km²) (7.49%) is water.
According to the Lake George Association Lake George is 32 miles in length and
a maximum of 2 miles in width.[8]

The [Adirondack Northway](/wiki/Interstate_87_\(New_York\)#Adirondack_Northway
"Interstate 87 \(New York\)") passes through the town.

The last remaining [Howard Johnson's](/wiki/Howard_Johnson%27s "Howard
Johnson's") restaurant is located in Lake George.[9]

As of the [census](/wiki/Census "Census")[2] of 2000, there were 3,578 people,
1,533 households, and 1,002 families residing in the town. The [population
density](/wiki/Population_density "Population density") was 118.3 people per
square mile (45.7/km²). There were 2,456 housing units at an average density
of 81.2 per square mile (31.4/km²). The racial makeup of the town was 97.74%
[White](/wiki/White_\(U.S._Census\) "White \(U.S. Census\)"), 0.53%
[Black](/wiki/African_American_\(U.S._Census\) "African American \(U.S.
Census\)") or [African American](/wiki/Race_\(United_States_Census\) "Race
\(United States Census\)"), 0.25% [Native
American](/wiki/Native_American_\(U.S._Census\) "Native American \(U.S.
Census\)"), 0.59% [Asian](/wiki/Asian_\(U.S._Census\) "Asian \(U.S.
Census\)"), 0.03% [Pacific Islander](/wiki/Pacific_Islander_\(U.S._Census\)
"Pacific Islander \(U.S. Census\)"), 0.17% from other races, and 0.70% from
two or more races. [Hispanic](/wiki/Hispanic_\(U.S._Census\) "Hispanic \(U.S.
Census\)") or [Latino](/wiki/Latino_\(U.S._Census\) "Latino \(U.S. Census\)")
of any race were 0.92% of the population.

There were 1,533 households out of which 27.2% had children under the age of
18 living with them, 50.8% were [married couples](/wiki/Marriage "Marriage")
living together, 9.8% had a female householder with no husband present, and
34.6% were non-families. 28.1% of all households were made up of individuals
and 9.8% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The
average household size was 2.33 and the average family size was 2.84.

In the town, the population was spread out with 21.7% under the age of 18,
6.8% from 18 to 24, 25.8% from 25 to 44, 30.8% from 45 to 64, and 14.9% who
were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 42 years. For every 100
females, there were 103.5 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there
were 100.1 males.

The median income for a household in the town was $42,125, and the median
income for a family was $48,789. Males had a median income of $31,134 versus
$22,375 for females. The [per capita income](/wiki/Per_capita_income "Per
capita income") for the town was $22,311. About 3.6% of families and 6.8% of
the population were below the [poverty line](/wiki/Poverty_line "Poverty
line"), including 7.2% of those under age 18 and 6.3% of those age 65 or over.

##
Communities[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lake_George,_New_York&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Communities")]

  * Big Hollow – A [hamlet](/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_New_York#Hamlet "Administrative divisions of New York") northwest of Lake George village.
  * Bloody Pond – A [pond](/wiki/Pond "Pond") in the south part of town that got its name from the [Battle of Lake George](/wiki/Battle_of_Lake_George "Battle of Lake George").
  * Crosbyside – A hamlet east of Lake George village.
  * Diamond Point – A hamlet north of Lake George village on the west shore of Lake George. This hamlet has [ZIP code](/wiki/ZIP_code "ZIP code") 12824.
  * [Fort William Henry](/wiki/Fort_William_Henry "Fort William Henry") – The reconstructed historic fort is in Lake George village, originally built by the British during the [French and Indian War](/wiki/French_and_Indian_War "French and Indian War").
  * [Lake George](/wiki/Lake_George_\(village\),_New_York "Lake George \(village\), New York") – A village located at the south end of Lake George.
  * [Prospect Mountain](/wiki/Prospect_Mountain_\(Warren_County,_New_York\) "Prospect Mountain \(Warren County, New York\)") – A mountain near Big Hollow.
